statement.tex: \text{Examine the continuity of}\\ \qquad f(x) = x - 5 \\ \text{In other words, find all the points}\\ \text{- if any - where f(x) is discontinuous.}

step.context: \text{Your friend says, }\\ \textbf{Pick some 10,20 or 30 points. If f(x)}\\ \textbf{is continuous there, then it is continuous}\\ \textbf{everywhere}\\ \text{Is he/she right in saying so?}
step.tex: \textbf{No.} \text{ To prove that f(x) is continuous}\\ \text{everywhere, we must prove continuity at all x.}
step.reason: \text{Even if you test for continuity at a }\\ \text{billion points, there would be another billion}\\ \text{points you wouldn't have tested for.}\\ \text{A truly mathematical proof would therefore }\\ \text{start by proving or disproving continuity at }\\ \text{a general point }x = C.

step.context: \text{Given f(x), what is the condition for}\\ \text{continuity at }x = C ?
step.reason: \text{For a function to be continuous at a point}\\ \textbf{two conditions}\text{ must be satisfied}\\ \begin{tabular}{l|c} \hline \text{In English} & \text{Mathematically} \\ \hline \text{The function must approach} & \\ \text{the same value from the left } & \\ \text{and the right} & \lim_{x\to a}f(x)\text{ exists.}\\ \text{And that value should be} & \\ \text{equal to the value of the} & \\ \text{function at that point} & \lim_{x\to a}f(x) = f(a) \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \text{This also means that wherever a function is}\\ \text{continuous, it can be drawn without lifting}\\ \text{the pencil.}

step.context: \text{Given the conditions for continuity, are}\\ \text{the following analysis and conclusions correct?}
step.tex: \begin{tabular}{c|c|c|c} \\ \lim_{x\to C^-}f(x) & \lim_{x\to C^+}f(x) & f(C) & \text{Continuous?} \\ \hline C-5 & C-5 & C-5 & \text{Yes}\\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ \textbf{As C can be anything, }\text{ f(x) is }\\ \text{continuous everywhere.}
step.reason: \text{If your calculations are correct, then you will}\\ \text{find that }\lim_{x\to C}f(x) = f(C) \implies \text{continuity }\\ \text{at }x=C.\text{ And as C can be anything, }\\ f(x)\text{ is continuous everywhere.}\\ \text{Also, note that }f(x)\text{ is a straight line.}\\ \text{And straight lines are continuous.}
